sp.diag: I'm sorry I was in no condition to receive you when you called on me last night.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It doesn't matter.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: Ah, for special friends of Rick's we have a special discount. One hundred francs. He replaces the second sign with a third which reads "100 francs."

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Your story had me a little confused. Or maybe it was the bourbon.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: I have some tablecloths, some napkins --

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: -- Thank you. I'm really not interested.

sp.speaker: ARAB
sp.diag: Please, one minute. Wait! The Arab hurriedly exits. Ilsa pretends to examine the goods on the counter.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why did you come back? To tell me why you ran out on me at the railway station?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, you can tell me now. I'm reasonably sober.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I don't think I will, Rick.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why not? After all, I got stuck with a railway ticket. I think I'm entitled to know.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Last night I saw what has happened to you. The Rick I knew in Paris, I could tell him. He'd understand. But the one who looked at me with such hatred-- well, I'll be leaving Casablanca soon and we'll never see each other again. We knew very little about each other when we were in love in Paris. If we leave it that way, maybe we'll remember those days and not Casablanca, not last night.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Did you run out on me because you couldn't take it? Because you knew what it would be like, hiding from the police, running away all the time?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You can believe that if you want to.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, I'm not running away any more. I'm settled now, above a saloon, it's true, but-- walk up a flight. I'll be expecting you. Ilsa turns her head away.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All the same, someday you'll lie to Laszlo. You'll be there.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: No, Rick. No, you see, Victor Laszlo is my husband-- and was, even when I knew you in Paris. She walks away into the cafe as Rick stares after her in stunned disbelief.

scene.setting: INT. THE BLUE PARROT - DAY Ilsa and Laszlo sit with Ferrari.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: I was just telling Monsieur Laszlo that, unfortunately, I am not able to help him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: You see, my dear, the word has gone around.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: to Ilsa As leader of all illegal activities in Casablanca, I am an influential and respected man. It would not be worth my life to do anything for Monsieur Laszlo. You, however, are a different matter.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Signor Ferrari thinks it might just be possible to get an exit visa for you.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You mean for me to go on alone?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: And only alone.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I will stay here and keep on trying. I'm sure in a little while --

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: -- We might as well be frank, Monsieur. It will take a miracle to get you out of Casablanca. And the Germans have outlawed miracles.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: We are only interested in two visas, Signor.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Please, Ilsa, don't be hasty.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: firmly No, Victor, no.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: You two will want to discuss this. Excuse me. I'll be at the bar. Ferrari gets to his feet and walks away.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: No, Ilsa, I won't let you stay here. You must get to America. And believe me, somehow I will get out and join you.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: But, Victor, if the situation were different, if I had to stay and there were only a visa for one, would you take it?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: not very convincingly Yes, I would. Ilsa smiles faintly. She doesn't believe it for even a moment.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes, I see. When I had trouble getting out of Lille, why didn't you leave me there? And when I was sick in Marseilles and held you up for two weeks and you were in danger every minute of the time, why didn't you leave me then?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I meant to, but something always held me up. I love you very much, Ilsa. She smiles again.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Your secret will be safe with me. Ferrari is waiting for our answer. At the bar Ferrari talks to a waiter.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Not more than fifty francs though. Ilsa and Laszlo walk up to him.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We've decided, Signor Ferrari. For the present we'll go on looking for two exit visas. Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Well, good luck. But be careful. a flick of his eyes in the direction of the bazaar You know you're being shadowed? Laszlo glances in the direction of the bazaar.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Of course. It becomes an instinct. Ferrari looks shrewdly at Ilsa.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: I observe that you in one respect are a very fortunate man, Monsieur. I am moved to make one more suggestion, why, I do not know, because it cannot possibly profit me, but, have you heard about Signor Ugarte and the letters of transit?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes, something.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Those letters were not found on Ugarte when they arrested him. There's a moments pause as this sinks in.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Do you know where they are?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Not for sure, Monsieur, but I will venture to guess that Ugarte left those letters with Monsieur Rick. Ilsa's face darkens. Laszlo quietly observes.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Rick?

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: He is a difficult customer, that Rick. One never knows what he'll do or why. But it is worth a chance.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you very much. Good day.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Goodbye, thank you for your coffee, Signor. I shall miss that when we leave Casablanca. Ferrari bows.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: It was gracious of you to share it with me. Good day, Mademoiselle, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Good day. As Ilsa and Laszlo leave the cafe, Ferrari nonchalantly swats a fly on a table.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT Outside Rick's cafe, the sign is lit up and MUSIC filters out into the air.
INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT At the bar, the European has found another TOURIST.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Here's to you, sir.

sp.speaker: TOURIST
sp.diag: Er, good luck, yes.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: I'd better be going.

sp.speaker: TOURIST
sp.diag: Er, my check, please.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: I have to warn you, sir. I beseech you-- The European picks his pocket.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: This is a dangerous place, full of vultures. Vultures everywhere! Thanks for everything. The tourist laughs.

sp.speaker: TOURIST
sp.diag: Er, goodbye, sir.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: It has been a pleasure to meet you. He dashes off and collides with Carl.

sp.speaker: EUROPEAN
sp.diag: Oh, I'm sorry. As the European hurries away, Carl checks all his pockets to make sure nothing is missing. Sam and Corina play a number, accompanied by the orchestra. Strasser and his crowd enter the cafe and pass Rick's table. Carl brings Rick a bottle and glass.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick, you are getting to be your best customer. Carl leaves. As Rick lights a cigarette, Renault shows up.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, Ricky. I'm very pleased with you. Now you're beginning to live like a Frenchman.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: That was some going-over your men gave my place this afternoon. We just barely got cleaned up in time to open. He pours a drink for Renault.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, I told Strasser he wouldn't find the letters here. But I told my men to be especially destructive. You know how that impresses Germans? taking a sip Rick, have you got these letters of transit?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Louis, are you pro-Vichy or Free French?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Serves me right for asking a direct question. The subject is closed.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, it looks like you're a little late.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Huh? Rick gazes at Yvonne and a GERMAN OFFICER approaching the bar.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: So Yvonne's gone over to the enemy.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Who knows? In her own way she may constitute an entire second front. I think it's time for me to flatter Major Strasser a little. I'll see you later, Rick. Renault gets up and strolls away. At the bar, Yvonne and the German officer place their orders.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Sacha!

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: French seventy-fives. Yvonne is somewhat drunk already.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Put up a whole row of them, Sacha-- starting here and ending here. She indicates with her hand where she wants them.

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: We will begin with two. A FRENCH OFFICER at the bar makes a remark to Yvonne.

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: in French Say, you, you are not French to go with a German like this!

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: in French What are you butting in for?

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: in French I am butting in --

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: breaking in, in French -- It's none of your business!

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: in French No, no, no, no! One minute! in English What did you say? Would you kindly repeat it?

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: What I said is none of your business!

sp.speaker: GERMAN OFFICER
sp.diag: I will make it my business! They begin to fight.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: in French Stop! I beg of you! I beg of you, stop! There are exclamations from people nearby. German officers at a nearby table rise, ready to join in. Rick walks up and separates the two men.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to the German I don't like disturbances in my place. Either lay off politics or get out.

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: in French Dirty Boche. Someday we'll have our revenge! Renault, Strasser and the other officers sit down again.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You see, Captain, the situation is not as much under control as you believe.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: My dear Major, we are trying to cooperate with your government, but we cannot regulate the feelings of our people. Strasser eyes him closely.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Captain Renault, are you entirely certain which side you're on?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I have no conviction, if that's what you mean. I blow with the wind, and the prevailing wind happens to be from Vichy.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: And if it should change? He smiles.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Surely the Reich doesn't admit that possibility? Renault lights a cigarette and puffs away.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: We are concerned about more than Casablanca. We know that every French province in Africa is honey-combed with traitors waiting for their chance, waiting, perhaps, for a leader.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: casually A leader, like Laszlo?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Uh, huh. I have been thinking. It is too dangerous if we let him go. It may be too dangerous if we let him stay.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: thoughtfully I see what you mean. Carl, bottle in hand, approaches the table of a middle-aged German couple, the LEUCHTAGS.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: in German I brought you the finest brandy. Only the employees drink it here. He pours a drink for each of them. MR. LEUCHTAG Thank you, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: as he pours For Mrs. Leuchtag. MRS. LEUCHTAG Thank you, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: For Mr. Leuchtag. MR. LEUCHTAG Carl, sit down. Have a brandy with us. MRS. LEUCHTAG beaming with happiness To celebrate our leaving for America tomorrow. Carl sits down.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Thank you very much. I thought you would ask me, so I brought the good brandy and a third glass. He produces a glass from a back pocket. MRS. LEUCHTAG At last the day has came. MR. LEUCHTAG Frau Leuchtag and I are speaking nothing but English now. MRS. LEUCHTAG So we should feel at home ven ve get to America.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: A very nice idea. MR. LEUCHTAG raising his glass To America. Mrs. Leuchtag and Carl repeat "To America." They clink glasses and drink. MR. LEUCHTAG Liebchen, uh, sweetness heart, what watch? She glances at her wristwatch. MRS. LEUCHTAG Ten watch. MR. LEUCHTAG surprised Such much?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Er, you will get along beautifully in America, huh. Annina meets Renault in the hallway as she leaves the gambling room,

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: How's lady luck treating you? Aw, too bad. You'll find him over there. Annina sees Rick and goes to his table.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Could I speak to you for just a moment, please? Rick looks at her.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How did you get in here? You're under age.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: I came with Captain Renault.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: cynically I should have known.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: My husband is with me, too.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He is? Well, Captain Renault's getting broadminded. Sit down. Will you have a drink? Annina shakes her head.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No, of course not. Do you mind if I do?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: No. Rick pours himself a drink

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick, what kind of man is Captain Renault?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, he's just like any other man, only more so.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: No, I mean, is he trustworthy? Is his word --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Now, just a minute. Who told you to ask me that?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: He did. Captain Renault did.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I thought so. Where's your husband?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: At the roulette table, trying to win enough for our exit visa. Well of course, he's losing. Rick looks at her closely.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How long have you been married?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Eight weeks. We come from Bulgaria. Oh, things are very bad there, Monsieur. A devil has the people by the throat. So, Jan and I, we, we do not want our children to grow up in such a country.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: wearily So you decided to go to America.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Yes, but we have not much money, and travelling is so expensive and difficult. It was much more than we thought to get here. And then Captain Renault sees us and he is so kind. He wants to help us.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, I'll bet.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: He tells me he can give us an exit visa, but we have no money.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Does he know that?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, yes.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And he is still willing to give you a visa?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Yes, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And you want to know --

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: -- Will he keep his word?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: He always has. There is a silence. Annina is very disturbed.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, Monsieur, you are a man. If someone loved you very much, so that your happiness was the only thing that she wanted in the whole world, but she did a bad thing to make certain of it, could you forgive her? Rick stares off into space.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Nobody ever loved me that much.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: And he never knew, and the girl kept this bad thing locked in her heart? That would be all right, wouldn't it?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: harshly You want my advice?

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, yes, please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go back to Bulgaria.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Oh, but if you knew what it means to us to leave Europe, to get to America! Oh, but if Jan should find out! He is such a boy. In many ways I am so much older than he is.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, well, everybody in Casablanca has problems. Yours may work out. You'll excuse me. Rick abruptly rises.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: tonelessly Thank you, Monsieur. He quickly goes off, leaving Annina alone at the table. She remains seated, too demoralized to move. While Rick checks the reservation list, Ilsa and Laszlo enter the cafe. In the background we hear Sam playing, ironically enough, "It Had to Be You." Rick greets Ilsa and Laszlo.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Good evening.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Good evening. You see, here we are again.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I take that as a great compliment to Sam. to Ilsa I suppose he means to you Paris of, well, happier days. Laszlo looks around.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: quietly He does. Could we have a table close to him?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: And as far away from Major Strasser as possible.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, the geography may be a little difficult to arrange. Rick snaps his fingers for the headwaiter.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Paul! Table thirty!

sp.speaker: HEADWAITER
sp.diag: to Ilsa and Laszlo Yes, sir. Right this way, if you please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Ilsa I'll have Sam play "As Time Goes By." I believe that's your favorite tune.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: smiling Thank you. Rick walks over to Sam and whispers something to him. Sam stops what he is playing and begins "As Time Goes By." He shakes his head as Rick leaves. A waiter appears at Ilsa and Laszlo's table.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Two cognacs, please.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - GAMBLING ROOM - NIGHT Jan sits at the roulette table. He has only three chips left and seems bewildered. As Rick comes up the croupier speaks to Jan.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Do you wish to place another bet, sir?

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: No, no, I guess not. Rick stands behind Jan.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Jan Have you tried twenty-two tonight? I said, twenty-two. Jan looks at Rick, then at the chips in his hand. He pauses, then puts the chips on twenty-two. Rick and the croupier exchange looks. The croupier understands what Rick wants him to do. He spins the wheel. Carl follows the proceedings, fascinated. The wheel stops spinning.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: in French Twenty-two, black, twenty-two. A winner. Renault, at a nearby table, takes notice of what is happening. The croupier pushes a pile of chips onto twenty-two and Jan reaches for it.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: not even looking at Jan Leave it there. Jan hesitates, then withdraws his hands. Carl continues to watch. The wheel spins. Nobody speaks while it spins. It stops.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Twenty-two, black. Another winner. The croupier shoves a pile of chips toward Jan.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: to Jan Cash it in and don't come back. Jan rises to go to the cashier. A CUSTOMER complains to Carl.

sp.speaker: CUSTOMER
sp.diag: Say, are you sure this place is honest?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: fervently Honest! As honest as the day is long! Meanwhile, Rick has walked over to the croupier.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How we doing tonight?

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Well, a couple of thousand less than I thought there would be. Rick smiles slightly and goes toward the door. Annina runs up to him and hugs him.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick, I --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- He's just a lucky guy.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: solicitously Monsieur Rick, may I get you a cup of coffee?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No thanks, Carl.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Monsieur Rick! Renault, seeing that Jan has won, gets up from his table to follow Rick. Jan and Annina stop him on the way.

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: Captain Renault, may I --

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: -- Oh, not here, please. Come to my office in the morning. We'll do everything business-like.

sp.speaker: JAN
sp.diag: We'll be there at six.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I'll be there at ten. I am very happy for both of you. Still, it's very strange that you won. He looks over and sees Rick.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Well, maybe not so strange. I'll see you in the morning.

sp.speaker: ANNINA
sp.diag: Thank you so much, Captain Renault.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT At the bar, Carl whispers in Sacha's ear. Sacha says "No!" and runs to Rick.

sp.speaker: SACHA
sp.diag: Boss, you've done a beautiful thing. He kisses Rick on both cheeks.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go away, you crazy Russian! Carl pours a brandy for Rick. Pretending not to do so, Rick glances in Ilsa's direction. Renault comes up to him.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: As I suspected, you're a rank sentimentalist.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yeah? Why?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: chidingly Why do you interfere with my little romances?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Put it down as a gesture to love.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: good-naturedly Well, I forgive you this time. But I'll be in tomorrow night with a breathtaking blonde, and it will make me very happy if she loses. Uh huh! He smiles and walks away. Laszlo comes up to Rick.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Monsieur Blaine, I wonder if I could talk to you?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go ahead.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Well, isn't there some other place? It's rather confidential, what I have to say.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: My office.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Right.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - OFFICE - NIGHT Rick and Laszlo sit and discuss Laszlo's dilemma.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: You must know it's very important I get out of Casablanca. It's my privilege to be one of the leaders of a great movement. You know what I have been doing. You know what it means to the work, to the lives of thousands and thousands of people that I be free to reach America and continue my work.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm not interested in politics. The problems of the world are not in my department. I'm a saloon keeper.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: My friends in the underground tell me that you have quite a record. You ran guns to Ethiopia. You fought against the fascists in Spain.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: What of it?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Isn't it strange that you always happened to be fighting on the side of the underdog?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes. I found that a very expensive hobby, too. But then I never was much of a businessman. Rick gets up, as does Laszlo.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Are you enough of a businessman to appreciate an offer of a hundred thousand francs?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I appreciate it, but I don't accept it.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I'll raise it to two hundred thousand.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: My friend, you could make it a million francs, or three, my answer would still be the same.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: There must be some reason why you won't let me have them.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: There is. I suggest that you ask your wife.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I beg your pardon?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I said, ask your wife.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: My wife? Laszlo looks at him, puzzled.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes. Rick and Laszlo hear MALE VOICES singing downstairs.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT A group of German officers stand around the piano singing the "Wacht am Rhein."
INT. RICK'S CAFE - BALCONY - NIGHT Rick stands at the balcony outside his office and watches the Germans below.
INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT At the bar, Renault watches with raised eyebrow.
INT. RICK'S CAFE - BALCONY - NIGHT Laszlo's lips are very tight as he listens to the song. He starts down the step.

INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Laszlo passes the table where Ilsa sits and goes straight to the orchestra. Yvonne, sitting at a table with her German officer, stares down into her drink. Laszlo speaks to the orchestra.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Play the Marseillaise! Play it! Members of the orchestra glance toward the steps, toward Rick, who nods to them. Laszlo and Corina sing as they start to play. Strasser conducts the German singing in an attempt to drown out the competition. People in the cafe begin to sing the "Marseillaise." After a while, Strasser and his officers give up and sit down. The "Marseillaise" continues, however. Yvonne jumps up and sings with tears in her eyes. Ilsa, overcome with emotion, looks proudly at Laszlo, who sings with passion. Finally the whole cafe stands, singing, their faces aglow. The song finishes on a high, triumphant note. Yvonne's face is exalted. She deliberately faces the alcove where the Germans are watching. She SHOUTS at the top of her lungs.

sp.speaker: YVONNE
sp.diag: Vive La France! Vive la democracie!

sp.speaker: CROWD
sp.diag: Vive La France! Vive la democracie! People clap and cheer. Strasser is very angry. He strides across the floor toward Renault who is standing at the bar.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: You see what I mean? If Laszlo's presence in a cafe can inspire this unfortunate demonstration, what more will his presence in Casablanca bring on? I advise that this place be shut up at once.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: innocently But everybody's having such a good time.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Yes, much too good a time. The place is to be closed.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: But I have no excuse to close it.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: snapping Find one. Several French officers surround Laszlo, offering him a drink. Renault thinks a moment, then blows a loud BLAST on his whistle. The room grows quiet, all eyes turn toward Renault.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: loudly Everybody is to leave here immediately! This cafe is closed until further notice! Clear the room at once! An angry murmur starts among the crowd. People get up and begin to leave. Rick comes quickly up to Renault.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How can you close me up? On what grounds?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I am shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on in here! This display of nerve leaves Rick at a loss. The croupier comes out of the gambling room and up to Renault. He hands him a roll of bills.

sp.speaker: CROUPIER
sp.diag: Your winnings, sir.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh. Thank you very much. He turns to the crowd again.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Everybody out at once! As the cafe empties, Strasser approaches Ilsa. His manner is abrupt but cordial.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Mademoiselle, after this disturbance it is not safe for Laszlo to stay in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: This morning you implied it was not safe for him to leave Casablanca.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: That is also true, except for one destination, to return to occupied France.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Occupied France?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Uh huh. Under a safe conduct from me.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: with intensity What value is that? You may recall what German guarantees have been worth in the past.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: There are only two other alternatives for him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: What are they?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: It is possible the French authorities will find a reason to put him in the concentration camp here.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: And the other alternative?

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: My dear Mademoiselle, perhaps you have already observed that in Casablanca, human life is cheap. Good night, Mademoiselle. She looks at him, understanding what he means. He bows and exits as Laszlo arrives at the table. They start out of the cafe.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: What happened with Rick?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We'll discuss it later.

scene.setting: INT. HOTEL HALLWAY - NIGHT Ilsa and Laszlo walk to their room.

INT. HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT Laszlo switches on the light as they enter. While Ilsa takes off some jewelry he walks to the window and peers out into the darkeness. Below and across the street, a man stands under an arch. Laszlo watches him, then draws down the shade.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Our faithful friend is still there.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Victor, please, don't go to the underground meeting tonight.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: soberly I must. Besides, it isn't often that a man has a chance to display heroics before his wife. He crosses to a table, takes a cigarette from a box, and strikes a match.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Don't joke. After Major Strasser's warning tonight, I am frightened.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: To tell you the truth, I am frightened too. Shall I remain here in our hotel room hiding, or shall I carry on the best I can? He lights the cigarette.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Whatever I'd say, you'd carry on. Victor, why don't you tell me about Rick? What did you find out?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Apparently he has the letters.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: But no intention of selling them. One would think if sentiment wouldn't persuade him, money would. Ilsa is now noticeably uncomfortable.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Did he give any reason?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: He suggested I ask you.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Ask me?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes. He said, "Ask your wife." I don't know why he said that. Laszlo turns off the light. Ilsa walks over to the couch and sits down.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Well, our friend outside will think we've retired by now. I'll be going in a few minutes. He sits down on the couch next to her. A silence falls between them. It grows strained. Finally.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Ilsa, I --

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: -- Yes?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: When I was in the concentration camp, were you lonely in Paris? Ilsa still cannot look at him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes, Victor, I was.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: sympathetically I know how it is to be lonely. very quietly Is there anything you wish to tell me?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: speaking low No, Victor, there isn't.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I love you very much, my dear. Ilsa finally turns to look at Laszlo.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes, Yes I know. Victor, whatever I do, will you believe that I, that --

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: -- You don't even have to say it. I'll believe. Goodnight, dear. He bends down and kisses her cheek.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Goodnight. She watches him go.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Victor! She gets up and follows him to the door. He opens it. In the slit of light from the hall we see Ilsa's face, now strained and worried. She hesitates for a moment, then.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Be careful.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Of course, I'll be careful. He kisses her on the cheek and goes out the door. She stands there for a few seconds, then crosses to look out of the window. The figure in the archway is gone. She sees Victor walking down the street and closes the blind again. Ilsa gets a cloak from the bedroom, and leaves the hotel room.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick and Carl sit by the bar and look over ledgers. Carl is busy figuring. He looks up at Rick.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Well, you are in pretty good shape, Herr Rick.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How long can I afford to stay closed?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Oh, two weeks, maybe three.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Maybe I won't have to. A bribe has worked before. In the meantime, everybody stays on salary.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Oh, thank you, Herr Rick. Sacha will be happy to hear it. I owe him money. Carl laughs.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Now you finish locking up, will you, Carl?

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: I will. Then I am going to the meeting of the --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: interrupting -- Don't tell me where you're going.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: I won't.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Goodnight, Monsieur Rick. Rick walks up the stairs to his apartment.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - APARTMENT - NIGHT Rick opens the door and goes inside the dark room. Light from the hall reveals a figure by the window. He lights a small lamp. Ilsa faces him, her face white but determined. Rick pauses for a moment in astonishment.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: How did you get in?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: The stairs from the street. Ilsa comes over to meet him.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I told you this morning you'd come around, but this is a little ahead of schedule. Well, won't you sit down?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Richard, I had to see you.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You use "Richard" again? We're back in Paris.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Please.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Your unexpected visit isn't connected by any chance with the letters of transit? It seems that as long as I have those letters I'll never be lonely.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You can ask any price you want, but you must give me those letters.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I went through all that with your husband. It's no deal.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I know how you feel about me, but I'm asking you to put your feelings aside for something more important.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Do I have to hear again what a great man your husband is? What an important cause he's fighting for?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It was your cause, too. In your own way, you were fighting for the same thing.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm not fighting for anything anymore, except myself. I'm the only cause I'm interested in. He walks over to the window and Ilsa follows.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Richard, Richard, we loved each other once. If those days meant anything at all to you --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: interrupting, harshly -- I wouldn't bring up Paris if I were you. It's poor salesmanship.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Please. Please listen to me. If you knew what really happened, if you only knew the truth --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: cutting in -- I wouldn't believe you, no matter what you told me. You'd say anything now to get what you want. Rick walks over to a table and opens a cigarette box, but finds it empty.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: You want to feel sorry for yourself, don't you? With so much at stake, all you can think of is your own feelings. One woman has hurt you, and you take revenge on the rest of the world. You're a, you're a coward, and a weakling. There are tears in her eyes now.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: No. Oh, Richard, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, but, but you, you are our last hope. If you don't help us, Victor Laszlo will die in Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: What of it? I'm going to die in Casablanca. It's a good spot for it. He turns away to light a cigarette, then back to Ilsa.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Now if you -- He stops short as he sees Ilsa holding a small revolver in her hand. It's pointed directly at him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: -- All right. I tried to reason with you. I tried everything. Now I want those letters. Get them for me.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I don't have to. I've got them right here.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Put them on the table.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: shaking his head No.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: For the last time, put them on the table.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: If Laszlo and the cause mean so much to you, you won't stop at anything. All right, I'll make it easier for you. He moves closer to her.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Go ahead and shoot. You'll be doing me a favor. Her hand drops down, and there are tears in her eyes again. She turns and walks away from him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Richard, I tried to stay away. I thought I would never see you again, that you were out of my life. Rick follows her and takes her in his arms. He presses her tight to him.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: The day you left, if you knew what I went through! If you knew how much I loved you, how much I still love you! Rick kisses her passionately. She is lost in his embrace.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - APARTMENT - LATER From his window, Rick watches the revolving beacon light at the airport. Ilsa sits on the couch. On a table before her rests a bottle of champagne along with two half-filled glasses. Rick walks over to her.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And then?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: It wasn't long after we were married that Victor went back to Czechoslovakia. They needed him in Prague, but there the Gestapo were waiting for him. Just a two-line item in the paper: "Victor Laszlo apprehended. Sent to concen-tration camp." I was frantic. For months I tried to get word. Then it came. He was dead, shot trying to escape. I was lonely. I had nothing. Not even hope. Then I met you.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Why weren't you honest with me? Why did you keep your marriage a secret? Rick sits down with Ilsa.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh, it wasn't my secret, Richard. Victor wanted it that way. Not even our closest friends knew about our marriage. That was his way of protecting me. I knew so much about his work, and if the Gestapo found out I was his wife it would be dangerous for me and for those working with me.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: When did you first find out he was alive?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Just before you and I were to leave Paris together. A friend came and told me that Victor was alive. They were hiding him in a freight car on the outskirts of Paris. He was sick, he needed me. I wanted to tell you, but I, I didn't care. I knew, I knew you wouldn't have left Paris, and the Gestapo would have caught you. So I-- well, well, you know the rest.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Huh. But it's still a story without an ending. What about now?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Now? I don't know. I know that I'll never have the strength to leave you again.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And Laszlo?

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh, you'll help him now, Richard, won't you? You'll see that he gets out? Then he'll have his work, all that he's been living for.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All except one. He won't have you. Ilsa puts her head on Rick's shoulder.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I can't fight it anymore. I ran away from you once. I can't do it again. Oh, I don't know what's right any longer. You'll have to think for both of us, for all of us.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All right, I will. Here's looking at you, kid.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: I wish I didn't love you so much. She snuggles closer to Rick.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT Laszlo and Carl make their way through the darkness toward a side entrance of Rick's. They run inside the entryway. The headlights of a speeding police car sweep toward them. They flatten themselves against a wall to avoid detection. The lights move past them.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: I think we lost them.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes. I'm afraid they caught some of the others.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Come inside. Come.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Laszlo and Carl enter and cross toward the bar, out of breath from their exertion.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Come inside. I will help you. Come in here.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you. Carl goes behind the bar.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: I will give you some water.

xml.scene: CUT TO: INT/EXT. RICK'S CAFE - APARTMENT - NIGHT Rick and Ilsa hear voices below. Rick crosses to the door. He opens it just enough to see below, and turns off the light. Ilsa stands just in back of him. She makes a move as if to go out to the balcony but Rick's pushes her back. She withdraws behind the door. Rick walks out to the balcony railing. INT. RICK'S CAFE - BALCONY - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick sees Carl attending to Laszlo, who appears to be injured. RICK Carl, what happened? Both Carl and Laszlo look up. CARL excitedly The police break up our meeting. Herr Rick! We escaped in the last moment. RICK Come up here a minute. Carl looks up wonderingly, then starts toward the stairway. CARL Yes, I come. RICK I want you to turn out the light in the rear entrance. It might attract the police. CARL But Sacha always puts out that light -- RICK -- Tonight he forgot. CARL Yes, I come, I will do it. Carl climbs the stairs.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - APARTMENT - NIGHT Carl enters Rick's apartment and sees Ilsa. He looks at Rick and says nothing.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: in a low voice I want you to take Miss Lund home.

sp.speaker: CARL
sp.diag: Yes, sir.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick comes down the stairs. Laszlo wraps one of the small bar towels around his cut wrist. Rick looks questioningly at the injured hand.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: It's nothing. Just a little cut. We had to get through a window. Rick walks to the bar, picks up a bottle, and pours a drink.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, this might come in handy.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Thank you.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Had a close one, eh?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes, rather. Laszlo takes a drink.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Don't you sometimes wonder if it's worth all this? I mean what you're fighting for?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: We might as well question why we breathe. If we stop breathing, we'll die. If we stop fighting our enemies, the world will die.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: What of it? Then it'll be out of it's misery. Rick reaches in his jacket for his cigarette case, opens it, and takes out a cigarette.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: You know how you sound, Monsieur Blaine? Like a man who's trying to convince himself of something he doesn't believe in his heart. Each of us has a destiny, for good or for evil.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, I get the point. Rick lights his cigarette.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I wonder if you do. I wonder if you know that you're trying to escape from yourself and that you'll never succeed.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You seem to know all about my destiny.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I know a good deal more about you than you suspect. I know, for instance, that you are in love with a woman. It is perhaps strange that we both should be in love with the same woman. The first evening I came here in this cafe, I knew there was something between you and Ilsa. Since no one is to blame, I, I demand no explanation. I ask only one thing. You won't give me the letters of transit. All right. But I want my wife to be safe. I ask you as a favor to use the letters to take her away from Casablanca.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You love her that much?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Apparently you think of me only as the leader of a cause. Well, I am also a human being. He looks away for a moment.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes, I love her that much. Suddenly there is a CRASH at the door of the cafe, followed by the forced entry of several gendarmes. A French officer walks in and addresses Laszlo.

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: Mr. Laszlo?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Yes?

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: You will come with us. We have a warrant for your arrest.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: On what charge?

sp.speaker: FRENCH OFFICER
sp.diag: Captain Renault will discuss that with you later.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It seems that destiny has taken a hand. Laszlo looks for a moment at Rick, then in dignified silence crosses to the officer. Together they walk toward the door. Rick's eyes follow them, but his expression reveals nothing of his feelings.

scene.setting: INT. RENAULT'S OFFICE - MORNING Renault sits at his desk and smokes while Rick nervously fingers his hat. They're interrupted by an orderly. Renault hands some forms to the orderly, who then exits, and the conversation continues.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: But you haven't any actual proof, and you know it. This isn't Germany or occupied France. All you can do is fine him a few thousand francs and give him thirty days. You might as well let him go now.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Ricky, I'd advise you not to be too interested in what happens to Laszlo. If by any chance you were to help him escape --

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- What makes you think I'd stick my neck out for Laszlo?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Because one, you've bet ten thousand francs he'd escape. Two, you have the letters of transit, now don't bother to deny it. And, well, you might do it simply because you don't like Strasser's looks. As a matter of fact, I don't like him either.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, they're all excellent reasons.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Don't count too much on my friendship, Ricky. In this matter I'm powerless. Besides, I might lose ten thousand francs.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You're not very subtle, but you are effective. I, I get the point. Yes, I have the letters, but I intend using them myself. I'm leaving Casablanca on tonight's plane, the last plane.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Huh?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And I'm taking a friend with me. One you'll appreciate.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: What friend?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Ilsa Lund. pause That ought to put your mind to rest about my helping Laszlo escape. The last man I want to see in America.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: You didn't come here to tell me this. You have the letters of transit. You can fill in your name and hers and leave any time you please. Why are you interested in what happens to Laszlo? Renault gets out of his chair and crosses to the front of his desk.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'm not. But I am interested in what happens to Ilsa and me. We have a legal right to go, that's true. But people have been held in Casablanca in spite of their legal rights. Renault retrieves a fresh cigarette from a box on his desk.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: What makes you think we want to hold you? Renault chain-lights his new cigarette with the old one.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Ilsa is Laszlo's wife. She probably knows things that Strasser would like to know. Louis, I'll make a deal with you. Instead of this petty charge you have against him, you can get something really big, something that would chuck him in a concentration camp for years. That would be quite a feather in your cap, wouldn't it?

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: It certainly would. Germany-- Vichy would be very grateful.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Then release him. You be at my place a half hour before the plane leaves. Renault sits back down in his chair.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'll arrange to have Laszlo come there to pick up the letters of transit, and that'll give you the criminal grounds on which to make the arrest. You get him, and we get away. To the Germans that last will be just a minor annoyance.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: puzzled There's still something about this business I don't quite understand. Miss Lund, she's very beautiful, yes, but you were never interested in any woman.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, she isn't just any woman. Rick stares at the floor, then looks back up at Renault.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I see. How do I know you'll keep your end of the bargain?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I'll make the arrangements right now with Laszlo in the visitor's pen.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Ricky, I'm going to miss you. Apparently you're the only one in Casablanca who has even less scruples than I.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, thanks.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Go ahead, Ricky. Renault presses a button on his desk, triggering a BUZZER. The door to Renault's office opens. Rick rises to go.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And by the way, call off your watchdogs when you let him go. I don't want them around this afternoon. I'm taking no chances, Louis, not even with you.

scene.setting: INT. THE BLUE PARROT - DAY A waiter brings tea to Rick and Ferrari, who sit alone at a table in a secluded nook off the main room.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Shall we draw up the papers, or is our handshake good enough?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: It's certainly not good enough. But since I'm in a hurry, it'll have to do. Ferrari pours a cup for Rick, who takes a sip.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Ah, to get out of Casablanca and go to America! You're a lucky man.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, by the way, my agreement with Sam's always been that he gets twenty-five percent of the profits. That still goes.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Hmmm. I happen to know that he gets ten percent. But he's worth twenty-five.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: And Abdul and Carl and Sacha, they stay with the place, or I don't sell.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: Of course they stay. Rick's wouldn't be Rick's without them.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Well, so long. Rick gets up, followed by Ferrari. They shake hands to seal the deal. He walks to the door, then stops and turns around.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Don't forget, you owe Rick's a hundred cartons of American cigarettes.

sp.speaker: FERRARI
sp.diag: I shall remember to pay it-- to myself. Rick leaves. Ferrari picks up a fly swatter from the table and swats at a fly.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT A car pulls quickly to a stop just outside the cafe. On the door a huge placard reads:

sp.speaker: CLOSED
sp.diag: By Order of the Prefect of Police

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick sits at a table inside and reads the letters of transit. He hears a KNOCK on the door and puts them away in his pocket. He opens the door and Renault walks in.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: You're late.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I was informed just as Laszlo was about to leave the hotel, so I knew I'd be on time.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I thought I asked you to tie up your watchdogs.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh, he won't be followed here. Renault looks around the empty cafe.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: You know, this place will never be the same without you, Ricky.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Yes, I know what you mean, but I've already spoken to Ferrari. You'll still win at roulette.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Is everything ready? Rick points at his breast pocket.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I have the letters right here.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Tell me, when we searched the place, where were they?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Sam's piano.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Serves me right for not being musical. They hear the CRUNCH of tires as a car pull up.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh. Here they are. You'd better wait in my office. Renault walks up the stairs to Rick's office.

scene.setting: EXT. RICK'S CAFE - NIGHT Laszlo pays the cab driver. Ilsa quickly walks toward the entrance.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: to driver Here.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT Rick opens the door. Ilsa rushes in. Her intensity reveals the strain she is under. Rick grabs her by both arms and pulls her close.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Richard, Victor thinks I'm leaving with him. Haven't you told him?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: No, not yet.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: But it's all right, isn't it? You were able to arrange everything?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Everything is quite all right.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Oh, Rick! She looks at him with a vaguely questioning look.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: We'll tell him at the airport. The less time to think, the easier for all of us. Please trust me. Ilsa pauses and looks at Rick, unsure for a moment.

sp.speaker: ILSA
sp.diag: Yes, I will. Laszlo comes in and closes the door behind himself.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: Monsieur Blaine, I don't know how to thank you.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Oh, save it. We've still lots of things to do. They all walk towards the bar. Laszlo deposits his hat on a a nearby table.

scene.setting: INT. RICK'S CAFE - OFFICE - NIGHT Renault opens the office door and peers down at the proceedings.
INT. RICK'S CAFE - MAIN ROOM - NIGHT

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: I brought the money, Monsieur Blaine.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Keep it. You'll need it in America.

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: But we made a deal.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: cutting him short Oh, never mind about that. You won't have any trouble in Lisbon, will you?

sp.speaker: LASZLO
sp.diag: No. It's all arranged.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Good. I've got the letters right here, all made out in blank. He takes out the letters.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: All you have to do is fill in the signatures. He hands them to Laszlo, who takes them gratefully.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Victor Laszlo! All three hear footsteps and turn to see Renault walking towards them from the bottom of the stairs.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Victor Laszlo, you are under arrest -- as he walks toward them on a charge of accessory to the murder of the couriers from whom these letters were stolen. Ilsa and Laszlo are both caught completely off guard. They turn towards Rick, bewildered. Horror is in Ilsa's eyes. Renault takes the letters.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Oh, you are surprised about my friend Ricky? Obviously the situation delights Renault. He smiles as he turns toward Rick.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: The explanation is quite simple. Love, it seems, has triumphed over virtue. Thank -- Suddenly the smile fades. In Rick's hand is a gun, which he levels at Renault.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: -- Not so fast, Louis. Nobody's going to be arrested. Not for a while yet.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Have you taken leave of your senses?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I have. Sit down over there.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Put that gun down. Renault then walks toward Rick. Rick puts out his arm to stop him.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Louis, I wouldn't like to shoot you, but I will, if you take one more step. Renault halts for a moment and studies Rick.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Under the circumstances, I will sit down. He walks to a table and sits.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: sharply Keep your hands on the table. He takes out a cigarette case.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: I suppose you know what you're doing, but I wonder if you realize what this means?

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: I do. We've got plenty of time to discuss that later.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: Call off your watch-dogs you said.

sp.speaker: RICK
sp.diag: Just the same, you call the airport and let me hear you tell them. And remember, this gun's pointed right at your heart.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: That is my least vulnerable spot. As Renault picks up the phone and dials, Rick takes back the letters.

sp.speaker: RENAULT
sp.diag: into phone Hello, is this the airport? This is Captain Renault speaking. There'll be two letters of transit for the Lisbon plane. There's to be no trouble about them. Good.

scene.setting: INT. GERMAN CONSULATE - NIGHT Strasser is on the phone.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: Hello? Hello? He hangs up the receiver and presses a BUZZER on his desk. An officer quickly enters.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: to officer My car, quickly!

sp.speaker: OFFICER
sp.diag: saluting Zu Befehl, Herr Major. The officer exits and Strasser resumes on the telephone.

sp.speaker: STRASSER
sp.diag: This is Major Strasser. Have a squad of police meet me at the airport at once. At once! Do you hear? He hangs up the receiver and, grabbing for his cap, hurriedly exits.

scene.setting: EXT. AIRPORT - NIGHT The entire airport is surrounded by a heavy fog. The outline of the transport plane is barely visible.

xml.scene:
CUT TO: INT/EXT. AIRPORT HANGAR - NIGHT A uniformed ORDERLY uses a telephone near the hangar door. On the airfield a transport plane is being readied. ORDERLY Hello. Hello, radio tower? Lisbon plane taking off in ten minutes. East runway. Visibility: one and one half miles. Light ground fog. Depth of fog: approximately 500. Ceiling: unlimited. Thank you. He hangs up and moves to a car that has just pulled up outside the hangar. Renault gets out while the orderly stands at attention. He's closely followed by Rick, right hand in the pocket of his trench coat, covering Renault with a gun. Laszlo and Ilsa emerge from the rear of the car. RICK indicating the orderly Louis, have your man go with Mr. Laszlo and take care of his luggage. RENAULT bowing ironically Certainly Rick, anything you say. to orderly Find Mr. Laszlo's luggage and put it it on the plane. ORDERLY Yes, sir. This way please. The orderly escorts Laszlo off in the direction of the plane. Rick takes the letters of transit out of his pocket and hands them to Renault, who turns and walks toward the hangar.
RICK If you don't mind, you fill in the names. That will make it even more official. RENAULT You think of everything, don't you? RICK quietly And the names are Mr. and Mrs. Victor Laszlo. Renault stops dead in his tracks, and turns around. Both Ilsa and Renault look at Rick with astonishment. ILSA But why my name, Richard? RICK Because you're getting on that plane. ILSA confused I don't understand. What about you? RICK I'm staying here with him 'til the plane gets safely away. Rick's intention suddenly dawns on Ilsa. ILSA No, Richard, no. What has happened to you? Last night we said -- RICK -- Last night we said a great many things. You said I was to do the thinking for both of us. Well, I've done a lot of it since then and it all adds up to one thing. You're getting on that plane with Victor where you belong.
ILSA protesting But Richard, no, I, I -- RICK -- You've got to listen to me. Do you have any idea what you'd have to look forward to if you stayed here? Nine chances out of ten we'd both wind up in a concentration camp. Isn't that true, Louis? Renault countersigns the papers. RENAULT I'm afraid Major Strasser would insist. ILSA You're saying this only to make me go. RICK I'm saying it because it's true. Inside of us we both know you belong with Victor. You're part of his work, the thing that keeps him going. If that plane leaves the ground and you're not with him, you'll regret it. ILSA No. RICK Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of your life. ILSA But what about us? RICK We'll always have Paris. We didn't have, we'd lost it, until you came to Casablanca. We got it back last night. ILSA And I said I would never leave you. RICK And you never will. But I've got a job to do, too. Where I'm going you can't follow. What I've got to do you can't be any part of. Ilsa, I'm no good at being noble, but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. Someday you'll understand that. Now, now-- Ilsa's eyes well up with tears. Rick puts his hand to her chin and raises her face to meet his own. RICK Here's looking at you, kid.

scene.setting: EXT. ROAD - NIGHT Major Strasser drives at break-neck speed towards the airport. He HONKS his horn furiously.

xml.scene:
CUT TO: INT/EXT. AIRPORT HANGAR - NIGHT Laszlo returns. Rick walks into the hangar and Renault hands him the letters. He walks back out to Laszlo. LASZLO Everything in order? RICK All except one thing. There's something you should know before you leave. LASZLO sensing what is coming Monsieur Blaine, I don't ask you to explain anything. RICK I'm going to anyway, because it may make a difference to you later on. You said you knew about Ilsa and me. LASZLO Yes. RICK But you didn't know she was at my place last night when you were. She came there for the letters of transit. Isn't that true, Ilsa?
ILSA facing Laszlo Yes. RICK forcefully She tried everything to get them, and nothing worked. She did her best to convince me that she was still in love with me, but that was all over long ago. For your sake, she pretended it wasn't, and I let her pretend. LASZLO I understand. RICK Here it is. Rick hands the letters to Laszlo. LASZLO Thanks. I appreciate it. Laszlo extends his hand to Rick, who grasps it firmly. LASZLO And welcome back to the fight. This time I know our side will win. On the airfield the airplane engine TURNS OVER and the propellers start turning. They all turn to see the plane readying for take-off. Ilsa looks at Rick and he returns her stare with a blank expression. He then glances at Laszlo, as does Ilsa. Then Laszlo breaks the silence. LASZLO Are you ready Ilsa? ILSA Yes, I'm ready. to Rick Goodbye, Rick. God bless you.
RICK You better hurry, or you'll miss that plane. Rick watches as Ilsa and Laszlo walk very deliberately towards the plane. RENAULT Well I was right. You are a sentimentalist.
RICK Stay where you are. I don't know what you're talking about. Rick puts a cigarette in his mouth. RENAULT What you just did for Laszlo, and that fairy tale that you invented to send Ilsa away with him. I know a little about women, my friend. She went, but she knew you were lying. RICK Anyway, thanks for helping me out. RENAULT I suppose you know this isn't going to be pleasant for either of us, especially for you. I'll have to arrest you of course. RICK As soon as the plane goes, Louis. The door to the plane is closed by an attendant and it slowly taxies down the field. Suddenly a speeding car comes to a stop outside the hangar. Strasser alights from the car and runs toward Renault. STRASSER What is the meaning of that phone call? RENAULT Victor Laszlo is on that plane. Renault nods toward the field. Strasser turns to see the plane taxiing towards the runway. STRASSER Why do you stand here? Why don't you stop him?
RENAULT Ask Monsieur Rick. Strasser looks briefly at Rick, then makes a step towards the telephone just inside the hangar door. RICK Get away from that phone. Strasser stops in his tracks, looks at Rick, and sees that he is armed. STRASSER steely I would advise you not to interfere.
RICK I was willing to shoot Captain Renault, and I'm willing to shoot you. Strasser watches the plane in agony. His eyes dart towards the telephone. He runs toward it and desperately grabs the receiver. STRASSER Hello? RICK Put that phone down! STRASSER Get me the Radio Tower! RICK Put it down! Strasser, one hand holding the receiver, pulls out a pistol with the other hand, and SHOOTS quickly at Rick. The bullet misses its mark. Rick now SHOOTS at Strasser, who crumples to the ground. At the sound of an approaching car both men turn. A police car SPEEDS in and comes to a stop near Renault. Four gendarmes hurriedly jump out. In the distance the plane turns onto the runway. The gendarmes run to Renault. The first one hurriedly salutes him. GENDARME Mon Capitaine! RENAULT Major Strasser's been shot. Renault pauses and looks at Rick. Rick returns Renault's gaze with expressionless eyes. RENAULT Round up the usual suspects. GENDARME Oui, mon Capitaine. The gendarmes take Strasser's body away and then drive off. Renault walks inside the hangar, picks up a bottle of Vichy water, and opens it. RENAULT Well, Rick, you're not only a sentimentalist, but you've become a patriot. RICK Maybe, but it seemed like a good time to start.
RENAULT I think perhaps you're right. As he pours the water into a glass, Renault sees the Vichy label and quickly DROPS the bottle into a trash basket which he then KICKS over. He walks over and stands beside Rick. They both watch the plane take off, maintaining their gaze until it disappears into the clouds. Rick and Louis slowly walk away from the hangar toward the runway.
RENAULT It might be a good idea for you to disappear from Casablanca for a while. There's a Free French garrison over at Brazzaville. I could be induced to arrange a passage. RICK My letter of transit? I could use a trip. But it doesn't make any difference about our bet. You still owe me ten thousand francs.
RENAULT And that ten thousand francs should pay our expenses.
RICK Our expenses? RENAULT Uh huh. RICK Louis, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship. The two walk off together into the night. FADE OUT: THE END
